To object to a state's Electoral College results, a member of the House & a member of the Senate must sign on.

Over the last 20 years, the Electoral College's results have been challenged several times. Notably in 2001, 2005 and 2017.

And you guessed it, all by Democrats.

1343970110093012993.text:
To object to a state's Electoral College results, a member of the House & a member of the Senate must sign on.

Over the last 20 years, the Electoral College's results have been challenged several times. Notably in 2001, 2005 and 2017.

1343970037196054532.text:
Second, the House & Senate must convene in a joint-session to review electoral votes.

Only after both chambers object or affirm the Electoral College's results is the President-Elect officially declared.

1343969865644859395.text:
Going all the way back to Rutherford B. Hayes' election in 1876, Congress has played a role in ensuring our elections are free & fair.

The Electoral Count Act of 1877 gives both the House & Senate the ability to object to Electoral College votes.

1343969721553739776.text:
First, each state is given electors based on population.

Electors across all states cast 1 vote which is certified by its respective state.

State ballots are then sent to the U.S. Congress to count, certify validity, object (or not) & declare the results (majority required).
